item.title: Sequence Determinants of the Conformational Properties of an Intrinsically Disordered Protein Prior to and Upon Multisite Phosphorylation
item.description: A groundbreaking exploration of how sequence patterning, especially proline and charge distributions, governs the conformational behavior of intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) even under multisite phosphorylation, with compensatory conformational changes maintaining overall dimensions.

item.title: Transient Non-native Hydrogen Bonds Promote Activation of a Signaling Protein
item.description: A groundbreaking study connecting protein folding energy landscapes to functional conformational changes in signaling proteins, showing how transient, non-native hydrogen bonds lower transition barriers and facilitate activation without unfolding.

item.title: The Conformational Plasticity of Protein Kinases
item.description: Notes on 2002 Cell review discussing conformational plasticity of protein kinases, highlighting key structural elements, activation mechanisms, and pseudosubstrate regulation. Includes insights on αC helix, activation loop, and therapeutic implications (e.g., Gleevec binding).

item.title: Activation of the Essential Kinase PDK1 by Phosphoinositide-Driven Trans-Autophosphorylation
item.description: Notes on the mechanism by which PDK1 is activated via PIP3-mediated dimerization and trans-autophosphorylation, highlighting the role of PH domain autoinhibition, linker-mediated dimerization, and switch-like activation mechanisms.
